body.p: Долго (ли) быть подобной срамоте, что феатральные люди не заплачены осьмой месяц! Я думаю разстаться с господином Стрекаловым вовсе, чтоб лишиться сего безпокойства, при всех прочих хлопотах. Прошу о сем наведаться подробно.On 6 February 1789, Khrapovitsky noted in his diary the receipt of this note: 'В вечеру поздно прислали записку, чтоб справиться, почему девятый месяц актерам не дают жалованья?' ('In the evening she sent a note to ask why for the ninth month the actors have not been given their salaries?'). The next day, on the 7th, he noted that they had an 'Изьяснение о безпорядках театра. Я пропозировал себя и Соймонова. Принято благосклонно. Взялся заготовить нужное') ('Discussion about the disorder of the theatre. I proposed myself and Soimonov. Favourably received. Undertook to prepare what is necessary'). On the 8th, Catherine and Khrapovitsky had extensive discussions about the theatre's debts, with Khrapovitsky drawing up several versions of the proposed ukazy. In a note of the same day, Catherine ordered Khrapovitsky to write an ukaz for the current theatre director Strekalov's dismissal and to insist on seeing the accounts and personally signing off on payments. On 10 February, Catherine signed off on one ukaz to the Cabinet, but left the rest of the ukazy until she had had time to further investigate the situation. Khrapovitsky, meanwhile, reassured her that he was not seeking the directorship of the imperial theatres: 'Еще я повторил, что на управление театрами я не напрашиваюсь'. Heated discussions between Khrapovitsky and the empress went on throughout February: on the 19th Khrapovitsky even begged on his knees to be dismissed from his post before leaving his final notes on the matter on her desk. Finally, on 2-3 March, Catherine signed orders handing over the direction of the theatres from Strekalov to Khrapovitsky and Soimonov and alloting 200,000 rubles to the theatres. (Dnevnik A.V. Khrapovitskago 1782-1793, pp. 250-59; 'Sobstvennoruchnyya pisma i zapiski Imperatritsy Ekateriny II-i k A.V. Khrapovitskomu, 1783-1793', columns 2086-87.)

Is such a disgrace to continue for long? The people working in the theatre have not been paid for eight months! I am thinking of parting ways with Mr. Strekalov entirely, so as to be rid of this trouble, alongside all my other worries. Please look into this in detail.
